Award.AwardTitle: STEM Colorado Teaching to Learn Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Phase II project is designed to integrate, expand, and align teacher preparation, induction, and mastery by bringing together Noyce Teacher Teams of current and prospective teachers with different types and levels of experience. The focus of each team of veteran, novice, and prospective teachers is on conducting classroom research and the goal of this centralizing activity is the critical examination of assumptions about teaching and learning. The mechanism by which such reflection occurs is scientific inquiry into one's own practice, the practices of others, and the practices of students. Team members collaborate on four different aspects of their own professional development, preparation, or induction program: (1) discipline-based educational research in the K-12 classroom, (2) implementation of state of the art technology and research-based approaches, (3) planning of and reflection on teaching and learning, and (4) conference presentations and journal publications. The Teaching to Learn project is a collaboration of the University of Colorado Boulder, Adams Twelve 5-Star Schools, Boulder Valley, Cherry Creek, Denver Public Schools, Englewood, Jefferson County, Mapleton, and St. Vrain Valley school districts associated with former Noyce projects. The Teaching to Learn research team activities serve as mechanisms both for the professional growth of participants and as a model for how scientific inquiry into personally and professionally meaningful problems leads to knowledge generation. The project is providing scholarships and stipends to 30 preservice teachers, including undergraduates and post-baccalaureate certification students. In addition to providing extended field experiences for preservice students, the project offers an expanded professional development program for recent and more experienced Noyce graduates supported under previous grants. The expectation that Noyce Teacher Teams publish and present their work leads to a greater impact on teacher-driven professional development nationwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome 1: At the conclusion of this award, 27 of the 41 total recruited Noyce scholars are currently teaching math and/or science in elementary, middle, and high schools, serving an estimated 3,200 students per year.

This project provided Noyce scholarship and stipend support to 29 undergraduate students and 12 post-BA students in their final stages of completing their licensure to teach K-12 math and/or science in Colorado. Of these individuals, 27 are currently teaching in high-needs school districts. Noyce scholars commit to teaching two years in a high-needs school district for each year that they receive scholarship support. So far, 23 participants of this project have fulfilled their teaching commitments and most have continued to teach beyond their commitment. Among these 23 teachers, the average teaching commitment is 2.4 years, however, this cohort has taught an average of 3.9 years (so far). An additional four participants are progressing towards their teaching commitments. Seven participants completed some teaching; four have delayed starting their teaching; three participants decided while they were still students that they no longer wanted to pursue math or science teaching and repaid their scholarships.

 

Outcome 2: Developed two induction models for recent Noyce graduates who have been teaching for 0-2 years. Our goal for these teachers is effective induction, leading to increased job satisfaction, self-efficacy, retention, and professionalization. 

Originally, this project proposed to sustain a "Teacher Research Team" model for purposes of supporting and retaining new teachers in the Noyce community. In this model, small teams of pre-service and practicing teachers collaborate on investigating problems of practice in their classrooms. Each of the 41 scholarship/stipend recipients participated on Teacher Research Teams while they were pre-service teachers. However, only four continued participating on Teacher Research Teams as they started to teach, and they all happened to be on the same math-focused team. We have evidence that although Noyce scholars benefit while they are still pursuing their teaching licensure, when they transition to teaching they don't have the capacity to fully participate and it was thus not meeting the needs of our new teachers. Thus towards the end of the project, we developed and piloted a new model, the Noyce Induction Teacher program, which has succeeded in retaining recent Noyce scholars in the community during their first years of teaching. This effort was led by two Master Teaching Fellows who are participants in the Streamline to Mastery project (NSF 1340083). Core elements of the Noyce Induction Teacher program are: (1) monthly face-to-face meetings co-constructed with the teachers to meet their needs, including 30 minutes of shared time with current Noyce scholars discussing a Problem of Practice and (2) paired mentor support by Master Teaching Fellows from the Streamline to Master project. Their work is structured around personalized professional growth plans and just-in-time mentoring where Noyce Induction Teachers led the focus of mentoring meetings by presenting issues or support they needed at that time. In the pilot year, five Noyce completers participated as Noyce Induction Teachers in their first year of teaching. All five returned for their second year, and seven additional participants joined them. This program will continue to be developed and studied as part of CU Boulder's current Noyce award, NSF 1557351.

 

Outcome 3: Broader Impacts

Although the Teacher Research Team model did not prove successful for supporting new teachers in our program, the project developed a large community of practicing teachers who engaged with each other and with Noyce scholars in the model. In total, 39 practicing teachers (including teacher leaders in the Streamline to Mastery project) engaged in classroom research with the 41 Noyce scholars. Teams disseminated what they learned by presenting their work and leading workshops at professional meetings, submitting publications, and engaging in other forms of professional development and leadership. In turn, many of these teachers are now serving as mentors for Noyce Induction Teachers in our new model of induction support. One of the most important outcomes of this entire project is the robust Noyce community that supports and challenges its members while providing opportunities for leadership development. This community membership and support is crucial as teachers attempt to continually improve educational experiences and outcomes for their own students.
